description:
Aquipuribacter hungaricus is a species of bacteria that was isolated from a freshwater lake in Hungary. It belongs to the phylum Proteobacteria and the class Gammaproteobacteria.

The cells of Aquipuribacter hungaricus are Gram-negative, non-spore-forming, and rod-shaped. They are aerobic, meaning they require oxygen for growth and metabolism. The optimum growth temperature for this species is around 25-30Â°C.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequencing has shown that Aquipuribacter hungaricus is most closely related to other bacteria within the genus Aquipuribacter, which are commonly found in aquatic environments.

The exact ecological roles and functions of Aquipuribacter hungaricus within the freshwater lake ecosystem are not yet fully understood. However, as a member of the Gammaproteobacteria class, it is likely involved in various biogeochemical processes and nutrient cycling in the lake.

Further research is needed to elucidate the specific metabolic capabilities, adaptations, and interactions of Aquipuribacter hungaricus within its natural habitat.
